thread.title: Man barricades himself in Tin Can Bay grocery store | The Courier-Mail
thread.title_full: Man barricades himself in Tin Can Bay grocery store | The Courier-Mail

title: Man barricades himself in Tin Can Bay grocery store | The Courier-Mail
text:
Man barricades himself in Tin Can Bay grocery store Jodie Munro O’Brien, Jacob Carson, Tom Daunt, The Courier-Mail February 8, 2017 2:50pm 
POLICE continue to negotiate with a man during a tense stand-off at the Tin Can Bay IGA after he barricaded himself in the store earlier and threatened to burn the building down. 
In the last half an hour the man has presented himself several times to police near a store entry and has had what can be described as a heated exchange. 
The man appears to be bailed up deep inside the IGA with a wooden pallet blocking an entrance. media_camera STANDOFF: Police are currently negotiating with a man inside the Tin Can Bay IGA. Picture: Tom Daunt 
Police presence has grown since the stand-off began with about 15 officers at the scene including negotiators. 
QFERS and QAS officers are still standing by. 
A large crowd has also gathered around the exclusion zone in an event that is disrupting the community in more ways than one. 
EARLIER: A MAN has allegedly barricaded himself inside a Tin Can Bay grocery store, causing police to remove onlookers and declare the area an emergent situation under the Public Safety Preservation Act. 
Police said the man is believed to be alone, but they established an exclusion zone, pushed onlookers back about 100 metres from the business and declared the emergent situation about 9.45am, The Gympie Times reports. 
The exclusion zone extends from the eastern side of Tin Can Bay Road to Gar St, the western side of Groper St to the northern side of Bass St and King St, the northern side of Gar St and the eastern side of The Esplanade to Parrott St and Toolara Rd. 
The man was allegedly threatening to burn down the IGA store. Emergency services were called to the scene about 7.30am, with a fire engine and four ambulances on standby on Gympie Rd. media_camera STANDOFF: Police are currently negotiating with a man inside the Tin Can Bay IGA. Picture: Tom Daunt 
Nearby business owners who spoke to The Gympie Times said the supermarket has been in dire financial straits since well before Christmas, and they believe the business was closed by the landlord early this morning. 
“We were informed it had been closed for not paying rent,” says Cooloola Coast Seafood owner Warren Sullivan. 
Mr Sullivan said the shop’s closure would be hard on the community. 
“Our nearest shop is eight kilometres out of town, and if you don’t have a car it’s too far to travel. 
“A lot of the miscellaneous things you can’t get anywhere else. 
“There’s been problems, people have gone on social media and said the shops were empty of stock, and there was a lot of complaints about that.” Most viewed
